column4: D. C.|Planetary and Space Science|102||119|Phobos’ parallel grooves
column5: which are such a striking feature of its surface
column6: have attracted interest since their discovery on Viking images in 1976 (Veverka and Duxbury
column9: but their origin is still in dispute today. The great increase in knowledge of Phobos’ surface features effected by images from the High Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) onboard the E.S.A. Mars Express spacecraft has clearly demonstrated that only one hypothesis can seriously be upheld: that the grooves are chains of secondary impacts resulting from primary impact events on Mars (Murray and Iliffe
column14: 21-41. DOI: 10.1144/SP356.3). But even this hypothesis has recently been questioned from a ballistic standpoint (Ramsley and Head
column16: 69-95.) mainly using estimated data for the grooves themselves. In the present paper we present summaries of extensive new measurements of groove sizes
column18: groove family parameters and geographical distribution. We also re-examine their unique characteristics
column19: and present a review of past ideas. But we concentrate on extending and refining the work of Ramsley & Head using the new measurements
column20: and the much-improved geodetic data from Mars Express (Willner et al.
column21: 2014. Planet. Space Sci. (2014)). We find that the total mass of Mars ejecta required to form all the observed grooves on Phobos is between 2.0×10<SUP>9</SUP> and 2.7×10<SUP>10</SUP> kg
column22: and that the total mass of impact ejecta from all Mars craters between 19 and 384 km diameter likely to hit Phobos (in its present orbit) at sufficient velocity to form all the grooves is one or two orders of magnitude greater than this. The larger available ejecta mass from Mars is due to several factors
column23: including the fact that Phobos is known to have orbited Mars at a greater distance at the time when the grooves were formed. A new rigorous celestial mechanical analysis of the transfer of ejecta from Mars to Phobos is presented
column24: including N-body calculations that model not only the gravitational interaction of Mars
column25: but also of Phobos and up to several hundred individual ejecta particles. This allows us to model the possible source areas on Mars of all observed groove families
column26: and to conclude that more than one groove family may have been formed by different batches of ejecta from the same Mars impact event
column27: and that the total number of Mars impact events responsible for creating the grooves may have been less than 10. The N-body calculations also allow us to model the complex gravitational interactions between Mars ejecta particles
column28: and thus to assess the contrast in groove morphometry between those families centred on the sub-Mars and anti-Mars hemispheres.

column1: 2010ACP....10.1911A|2010|Tropospheric photooxidation of CF<SUB>3</SUB>CH<SUB>2</SUB>CHO and CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>2</SUB>CHO initiated by Cl atoms and OH radicals|Antiñolo
column10: J.|Atmospheric Chemistry & Physics|10|4|1911|The absolute rate coefficients for the tropospheric reactions of chlorine (Cl) atoms and hydroxyl (OH) radicals with CF<SUB>3</SUB>CH<SUB>2</SUB>CHO and CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>2</SUB>CHO were measured as a function of temperature (263-371 K) and pressure (50-215 Torr of He) by pulsed UV laser photolysis techniques. Vacuum UV resonance fluorescence was employed to detect and monitor the time evolution of Cl atoms. Laser induced fluorescence was used in this work for the detection of OH radicals as a function of reaction time. No pressure dependence of the bimolecular rate coefficients
column12: was found at all temperatures. At room temperature k<SUB>Cl</SUB> and k<SUB>OH</SUB> were (in 10<SUP>-11</SUP> cm<SUP>3</SUP> molecule<SUP>-1</SUP> s<SUP>-1</SUP>): k<SUB>Cl</SUB>(CF<SUB>3</SUB>CH<SUB>2</SUB>CHO) = (1.55±0.53); k<SUB>Cl</SUB>(CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>2</SUB>CHO) = (3.39±1.38); k<SUB>Cl</SUB>(CF<SUB>3</SUB>CH<SUB>2</SUB>CHO) = (0.259±0.050); k<SUB>Cl</SUB>(CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>2</SUB>CHO) = (1.28±0.24). A slightly positive temperature dependence of k<SUB>Cl</SUB> was observed for CF<SUB>3</SUB>CH<SUB>2</SUB>CHO and CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>2</SUB>CHO
column14:
kOH(CF3(CH2)2CHO) did not exhibit a temperature dependence over the range investigated. Arrhenius expressions for these reactions were:

kCl(CF3CH2CHO) = (4.4±1.0)×10-11 exp{-(316±68)/T} cm3 molecule-1 s-1

kCl(CF3(CH2)2CHO) = (2.9±0.7)×10-10 exp{-(625±80)/T} cm3 molecule-1 s-1

kOH(CF3CH2CHO) = (7.8±2.2)×10-12 exp{-(314±90)/T} cm3 molecule-1 s-1

The atmospheric impact of the homogeneous removal by OH radicals and Cl atoms of these fluorinated aldehydes is discussed in terms of the global atmospheric lifetimes
column15: taking into account different degradation pathways. The calculated lifetimes show that atmospheric oxidation of CF<SUB>3</SUB>(CH<SUB>2</SUB>)<SUB>x</SUB> CHO are globally dominated by OH radicals
column16: however reactions initiated by Cl atoms can act as a source of free radicals at dawn in the troposphere.

column1: 1984ApJ...281..493Y|1984|Primordial nucleosynthesis : a critical comparison of theory and observation.|Yang
column10: K. A.|The Astrophysical Journal|281||493|Primordial nucleosynthesis is reexamined in the context of a detailed comparison of theory and observation. A new argument is presented to show how the observed abundances of D and <SUP>3</SUP>He can be used to derive a lower bound to the nucleon density. The authors define a conservative range for the nucleon-to-photon ratio: η = (3 - 10)×10<SUP>-10</SUP>. New observations of <SUP>7</SUP>Li are consistent with the abundances of D and <SUP>3</SUP>He and help to define a reasonable range: η = (4 - 7)×10<SUP>-10</SUP>. In either of these ranges the predicted and observed abundances of D
column12: and <SUP>7</SUP>Li are all in concordance. The upper bounds correspond to Ω<SUB>N</SUB> ≤ 0.14 - 0.19
column13: and it is concluded that nucleons fail to close the universe by at least a factor of 5 - 7. The authors review the recent observational data on <SUP>4</SUP>He and conclude that there is complete consistency between the predicted abundance of <SUP>4</SUP>He and those of the other light elements.
